discourse_list.title: A North Star - DAI as the Destination

content.content: Author(s): TJ Ragsdale (@teej) Contributors: Luca Prosperi (@luca_pro), Adrian (@adcv), Sébastien Derivaux (@SebVentures), Mark (@aes), Kevin Miao (@humancapitol)  References Charting a Path for RWAs - The Case For Continuity Aggressive Growth Strategy  Maker Growth Strategy - We Must Act Now A Balance Sheet Approach to Executing an Aggressive Growth Strategy  Preamble B2C over-collateralized crypto lending is a red ocean: it is a competitive business that is commoditizing before our eyes. Acquisition is expensive, churn is fairly high, and marginal revenue will trend toward zero. It’s time to look beyond the end of our noses and start positioning for the next source of demand for on-chain credit.  1064×692 1.21 MB   Increasing the Demand for Organic DAI Successful organizations align around a single, core mission. In my opinion, generating organic demand for DAI is MakerDAO’s raison d’être, it’s North Star. Organic demand is different than circulation, which is good but not enough. To onboard RWAs is to increase the circulation of, but not necessarily the organic demand for, DAI. (In a second-order kind of way, RWAs could increase organic demand, but let’s stick with first-order for now). When a real world asset manager opens a vault, it will most probably swap the DAI for fiat to achieve something off-chain, like developing real estate or repaying an existing financing line. DAI is a means to an end. On the other hand, when a crypto user opens a DAI vault, he or she will probably use the DAI proceeds themselves to achieve something on-chain, like providing liquidity. DAI is a destination. The reason we want to maximize organic DAI is that it is stickier. In the traditional world, a retail bank’s deposits are sticky (low redemption rate) and thus a stable source of funding for such institutions. Similarly, all DAI outstanding is a liability of the protocol—MakerDAO must always honor redemptions on demand, lest the market lose confidence in it. Accordingly, how MakerDAO might deploy capital productively is dictated by the nature of those liabilities. If redemptions are consistently rare (sticky DAI), then MakerDAO can take more and longer-dated risks on business initiatives (D3Ms, RWAs, etc.) that drive revenue to the protocol. This increased revenue will bolster the market’s perception of DAI, which drives more organic DAI demand, which opens up more diverse opportunities for revenue, and so on and so forth. Money is a network, and as such, we must focus on laying the rails for a network effect to take hold. Though many jeer at the unsustainable rewards Anchor currently bestows upon its disciples, both UST and DAI will live or die for the same reason: use cases or lack thereof.      Is DAI the Destination?     Crypto-Loans Yes   PSM Yes   D3M Sort Of   RWAs Not yet     Aggressive Growth - Framing the Fund Raise The core of MakerDAO is its direct crypto-loans business. This kernel should remain rigid, maximally decentralized, and permissionless. This business spits off revenue and will grow passively in lock-step with crypto’s market cap. Hopefully we will gain additional market share via L2s as those deployments roll out. The PSM, Maker’s second layer, should take on a bit more flexibility but also remain fairly rigid. The core mechanism shouldn’t change too much but its constituents may change as DAI strategically allies with other stables. The D3M and RWA layer is where Maker’s latent potential lies—through deployment here, a larger surplus buffer will usher in a new era of Aggressive and profitable growth. A matter of survival, experimentation will occur in the RWA and D3M petri dishes.  1310×655 57.7 KB  RWAs, as currently contemplated, are a huge opportunity for DAI circulation and revenue but not yet for organic DAI demand. Because the real world is mired in economic, technical, and legal path dependencies, DAI will not for a few years organically penetrate the existing capital markets. For it to do so would require “users” to change their behavior, which is not reasonable. As it should be, the community is committed to the pursuit of off-chain RWAs. We, RWF, will forge excellent partnerships with excellent managers. Not only will these vaults kick off a LOT of revenue, but the partnerships with established firms and companies will enhance and legitimize the Maker brand. As the RWA business matures, RWF will push to innovate on the RWA protocol. Through these efforts and the efforts of our peers, assets from the traditional world will soon live natively on-chain. But we can’t wait for that day—it is imperative to find PMF for organic DAI today. We need organic use cases that will shuttle DAI to Valhalla. Aggressive Growth will push ahead. In thinking about how MakerDAO should structure its imminent capital raise and in what quantum, we must consider the array of growth opportunities we, as a community, believe will deliver the specific properties most likely to drive success for MakerDAO. Only via measured consideration of the “uses” can we back into the capital markets “sources” intelligently.  798×368 95.7 KB   Start With Start-Ups  1600×1002 357 KB  Square’s inception was based on the premise of this diagram: that small businesses paid ~45x more for payment solutions than did larger ones in 2009. By enabling the digitization of SMB payments, Square unlocked the latent potential of and piggy-backed on the successes of its customers. The Square product was fine but it was the fit between its unique product and the right market (product-market fit) that was excellent. DAI is our product. Success, in my view, lies in organic uses for DAI, so how do we create more of these opportunities? As Paul G suggests, you put the product (DAI) in the hands of start-ups. Why starting with start-ups is a Zero to One:   Tabula Rasa: Start-ups are inherently more likely to adopt and use DAI organically.  DAO Jones: Today’s digital and crypto-native up-starts will be the household names of cyberspace in 2030. If this unicorn cohort is the DAO Jones, Maker should be JP Morganon.  Unique Positioning: Unlike with RWAs or crypto-loans, MakerDAO is uniquely positioned to infuse start-ups with DAI and unlock potential. No other lender has a native stablecoin. No other stablecoin issuer has a native lending business.   D3M - The Start-Up Spark Plug The D3M is currently the tool within Maker’s toolkit most broadly equipped to tackle this vision. Though I believe its current shape will morph, the D3M serves as a canary for what is to come, a hybrid approach—a crypto back-end, protocol-to-protocol, that enables commercial activity. The D3M is the pilot of MakerDAO as a wholesale lender—it lends to crypto-centric lenders like Aave and crypto-real world lenders like Maple or TrueFi, who then face borrowers directly. The D3M is interesting because it gives businesses, rather than individuals, predictable access to credit. Ultimately, the distinction between “RWAs” and the “D3M” will disappear. This happens via two parallel channels:    Real world rails themselves migrate natively on-chain     Asset constructs familiar to traditional finance (equities, bonds, derivatives) are issued by entities that live natively on-chain    As of now, the perceived difference between how MakerDAO categorizes RWAs and D3Ms lies in how risk is classified and thus which core units have the burden of assessment. The D3M, allegedly, incurs smart contract risk but not credit risk. RWAs, allegedly, incur credit risk but not really smart contract risk. Neither characterization is really correct. As we are realizing with the potential onboarding of Maple and TrueFi, not only does smart contract risk exist but also credit risk. With RWA integrations like Centrifuge, Maker incurs not only credit risk at the asset/borrower level but smart contract risk at the platform level. For the next cohort of MakerDAO assets, this bifurcation will be irrelevant. These assets may look and smell like traditional risk assets (equities, bonds, derivatives, real estate), but live completely on-chain. Rather than build on legal contracts, the next slew of start-ups will embed such assets into smart contracts.  1016×1232 66 KB  I think MakerDAO will and should take an increasingly barbelled approach to DAI generation. On one hand, it will lend to fintechs and DAOs in primarily a wholesale capacity. This will be done via a D3M-like wholesale lending mechanism but with thorough credit underwriting of the specialist lenders as well as their clientele (engineering + real world finance). We will call this B2B DAI. On the other side, MakerDAO will lend large amounts to retail and institutions directly against crypto and crypto-related assets in an accessible way for borrowers. We will call this EZ DAI.  Model 1: B2B DAI Acquiring and retaining consumers is hard in any space, never mind in crypto lending. Crypto borrowers have grown accustomed to rewards for adoption, which can result in expensive and dilutive emissions. We know that such incentivisation is not sustainable, but this is the state of things today nonetheless. The open-source nature of the ecosystem makes for even more treacherous conditions: vampire attacks, an endless slew of borrowing options, and a broad-brushed erosion of brand loyalty have become the norm. B2C lending is hard and only getting harder.  718×650 71.1 KB  *Source: Recurly Research By lending to businesses creating economic value, a lender’s financing is stickier, with lower acquisition and end-client management costs, and it can grow into the borrower’s commercial success. While the commercial lending market in TradFi is saturated, the on-chain commercial lending market is greenfield. MakerDAO should spearhead and unlock these credit markets, a blue ocean. By sizing credit risk appropriately, we’d start with a portfolio of small exposures and grow into these businesses. As the successful ones season and de-risk, MakerDAO would scale up the credit facilities, lighten the covenants and pricing, and enable these companies to grow unhindered into their potential.  1474×628 87.4 KB  Takeaway: There exists no institutional commercial lender for on-chain commerce. Capital markets for DAOs, or more broadly DAO-to-DAO finance, are still underdeveloped. In the coming months we will witness the genesis of the on-chain corporate bond market through platforms like Porter finance. Unlike their real world counterparts, many DAOs will opt to pay operating costs (indexing, payroll etc.) in DAI. More speculatively, I predict we will also see demand for native integrations of stablecoins into crypto gaming worlds: successful “metaverse” concepts (e.g. Crabada, Star Atlas, Illuvium) serve as the gateway for normies to enter our rarefied world. They will have vibrant capital, rental, commercial, and labor markets. Because [game] economies are so notoriously difficult to bootstrap and balance, a permissionless stablecoin integration may be an elegant solution. MakerDAO will, through rigorous credit underwriting of on-chain businesses and smart-contract guaranteed security interests in those businesses’ native assets, simultaneously mobilize dead capital, supercharge on-chain commerce, and generate strong risk-adjusted returns for MakerDAO’s treasury. MakerDAO is uniquely equipped to serve this role as THE on-chain wholesale lender.  Model 2: EZ DAI (DAI For Normies) Crypto vaults, where DAI is minted against Lindy assets like wBTC and ETH, are obviously ideal because the risk of loss is low (and monitorable) as long as the smart contracts are tight and the oracles are right. In their current formulation, crypto-vaults are great for the crypto-savvy but inaccessible to normies, whether individuals or institutions. Those uncomfortable with self-custody, changing borrowing rates, or just on-chain maneuvering cannot and will not use Maker—this leaves a ton of potential DAI demand untapped. To mobilize some portion of the crypto paralyzed in custodial wallets would be to expand the TAM for DAI drastically. A note on definitions: I will be using the term “Access Vaults” to describe what the MakerDAO community has historically called “Institutional Vaults” (e.g. Nexo, Celsius). These are aggregators who custody retail funds and wish to gain direct access to DAI liquidity. I will use the term “Corporate Vaults” to refer to vaults extended specifically to companies/institutions who do not necessarily face retail users. Access Vaults: The Nexos and the Celsiuses of the world, start-ups with a crypto back end and normie front end, are multiplying and taking on new forms. Contemporarily, most retail facing start-ups who deal in crypto are, in one form or another, exchanges. But this will change rapidly. As crypto continues to normalize and presumably become less volatile, we will see convenient avenues arise that allow people to monetize their crypto holdings as they would their S&P equities or homes. MakerDAO should tactically partner with start-ups who stand to benefit from this trend. To visualize, think about the invariable rise of the crypto-mortgage, or a loan secured by both crypto AND property. Start-ups like Figure and Moon Mortgage recognize that A) a straight mortgage is becoming unaffordable and B) that more and more potential borrowers hold crypto. So they combine the mortgagor’s (yes, the borrower is a mortgagor) crypto collateral with property collateral and offer better terms than competitors who are unable or unwilling to underwrite crypto. Like Nexo and Celsius, these sorts of companies will eventually have custody of hundreds of millions in retail crypto that they’ll want to access leverage and reinvest back into their businesses. MakerDAO must continually evolve and re-evaluate where the puck is going. To provide capital to exchanges is a crowded trade. Further, exchanges are a natural target for regulatory scrutiny—they’ll be sensitive to KYC/AML issues. How can we re-envision what form an “Access Vault” takes to ensure that DAI sails elegantly on the gales of creative destruction? Corporate Vaults: It may be too early for Bitcoin bonds, but crypto-secured term loans to corporate clients are on the menu. Silvergate Bank recently originated a $205MM bitcoin-backed loan to Saylor’s MicroStrategy. ETH and BTC will increasingly be used as treasury assets by sovereign wealth funds, central banks, and corporations. Accordingly, such entities will want to borrow at attractive rates against such holdings. As mentioned in the epilogue of “RWAs - The Case For Continuity”, a rising rate environment generates opportunity for cheap, predictable, fixed rate lenders. The cost of capital for corporates (and governments!) is rising and will probably continue to rise. At what point does it become a fiduciary imperative for a CFO to borrow more cheaply against crypto than he or she could in the corporate bond market? There is an opportunity here and savvy C-levels will seize it. MakerDAO is uniquely equipped to serve at this intersection—that of crypto and traditional credit underwriting. We have teams in-house to build out both the technical implementation of crypto-only vaults and the credit framework to provide more creative financing to particular clients. (e.g.imagine a crypto and ASIC-collateralized vault to a institutional miner).  Payments - The Final Piece A discussion about organic DAI demand would be incomplete without consideration for the last mile—payments. Without a gateway through which DAI natively flows into the real world, DAI fails to penetrate meatspace. We’d like for DAI to be a medium of exchange, not just for NFTs and crypto-commerce but for day-to-day purchases. Such a goal is practically impossible to realize on mainnet but there are obvious partnerships to pursue with cautious optimism.  “Who Controls Money Controls the World” - Kissinger The North Star for the Aggressive Growth Strategy and MakerDAO more broadly is to supercharge organic DAI demand—the journey towards DAI as money. If this is indeed the mission, then we should be orienting relentlessly towards the vehicles that will get us there. To me, RWAs in their current formulation are a stop-gap, a necessary shoehorning of DeFi into TradFi. But the next stage of Maker growth will be a unique form of financing that only MakerDAO can give life to. The D3M and RWAs will merge into a single deployment mechanism to infuse DAI into the ground-floor of a new, parallel, and uncorrelated economic engine.

Organic DAI demand is a powerful concept. This entails getting DAI into the hands of people or organizations that are happy to hold onto it rather than sell it for another asset. Organic demand is the most sustainable way to grow the usage and market cap of DAI. Just as traditional companies hold USD on their balance sheets and pay workers in dollars, DAOs should be holding DAI in their treasuries and paying contributors in DAI. DAOs and their contributors are a key source of organic demand because they believe in DAI due to its ubiquity throughout DeFi. As the founder of Porter Finance, I am incredibly excited to help bring DAI to DAOs through credit facilities and make DAI the predominant currency of commerce for on-chain businesses.

Thoroughly enjoyed this piece. Where would you position Dai on digital wallets as a lever for adoption - I believe this will be EZ Dai, correct? I have noticed for this, often in LatAm, that they provide extra services including exchange capabilities in addition to payment rails / Visa cash back card. While there is greater convenience along the transaction supply chain for users in that region, by underwriting Dai to provide a positive return for holders (and the Access Vault), Maker can take some of the marketshare that these digital wallets earn from their customers with stable coins. An example of this would be Lemon Cash. They have seen hockey stick growth this past year. Perhaps we can propose a regional priority across classifications. As CPI and regulation are unique across the fintech stack, we should also prioritize adoption to understand the hiccups for growth at scale. I am of the personal opinion that the greater we continue to maintain our finger on the pulse here, we will become more competitive in this hyper competitive space down the road. The additionality when closely considered could have a snowballing effect.

teej:  For the next cohort of MakerDAO assets, this bifurcation will be irrelevant. These assets may look and smell like traditional risk assets (equities, bonds, derivatives, real estate), but live completely on-chain. Rather than build on legal contracts, the next slew of start-ups will embed such assets into smart contracts.   This is so true.  The early innovation happening in on-chain RW financing today is creating the building blocks that all financial innovation (and fintech more broadly) will be building on in the future.  Atm we have clear distinctions between ‘on-chain’ and ‘off-chain’ financing, but soon we’ll have less need for those terms, as more RW financing just occurs on DeFi rails. This also highlights the importance of startups working together.  It’s a positive sum game - the rising tide of RWAs on-chain lifts all boats.

This piece is spot on in articulating that credit risk exists and is fundamental to understand any D3Ms overall value proposition to Maker. I’m not sure I understand this sentence “Ultimately, the distinction between “RWAs” and the “D3M” will disappear.” My understanding that D3M is a technology and can obviously be underpinned by digital native collateral or real world collateral. I think it’s confusing to say the distinction will disappear as RWAs can enter through other technology solutions provided by Maker. @teej could you clarify that one a bit more? The other question I have is prioritizing / choosing D3M technology solution over other technologies provided by Maker specific to RWAs Where is the best place to learn about that on the Forum and best point of contact for helping me understand that more deeply? Great thinking as always and keep it coming!

great article - but Maker needs to focus and execute on the key vision. Growing organic DAI demand is should be Maker’s defining vision. Also lets accelerate these key elements of the bigger Organic DAI Growth strategy     teej:  The D3M and RWAs will merge into a single deployment mechanism to infuse DAI into the ground-floor of a new, parallel, and uncorrelated economic engine.

100% aligned on this vision! I’ve been quietly making the case here and there that we need to pay attention to the social token sector and rapid emergence of DAOs as an internet-native organizational model that not only points to Web3 being the future of the internet, but DAOs as the future of everything.     teej:  Capital markets for DAOs, or more broadly DAO-to-DAO finance, are still underdeveloped.     to put it mildly. I swim daily in this DAO2DAO space. Three DAOs I will highlight below illustrate the opportunity. dOrg ACREinvest works with a Web3 developer collective called dOrg as collaborators in ACRE DAOs, a Web3 impact investment community we co-founded and sponsor. We pay invoices from dOrg entirely in DAI. This is organic demand… both from my firm AND our collaborators who do not want to take price risk by accepting payment in ETH (for example). Time magazine thinks our approach is pretty interesting: No Bosses: What It's Like Working at a DAO | Time  Salaries are transparent When it comes to pay rates and finances, dOrg aims for “radical transparency.” All salaries and budgeting are publicly maintained on the blockchain; payout logs are visible to each member. And employees are paid according to their skillset no matter where they live in the world. Amesty, who moved to Madrid from Venezuela after joining the company, says that when he previously tried to work for Latin American agencies, “they usually strong-armed developers to work for lower wages, because they know that Venezuela is in a very hard situation. After I started to work with dOrg, feeling my nationality didn’t matter—it was my work and what I was delivering.” In another interesting wrinkle, employees who work on specific projects can elect to either get paid in cash, or in tokens that represent an ownership stake in those projects. If they choose that latter option, they are sacrificing immediate spending money in favor of the idea that the valuation of the tokens will increase as their projects mature.  PrimeDAO Check out what PrimeDAO is doing to support native token liquidity and treasury diversification for tokenized communities. The opportunity for MakerDAO and/or the DAI Foundation @sorenpeter to creatively partner here is HUUUUGE.   primedao.mirror.xyz    The Next Stage of DAO Evolution: Networked Cooperation, Powered by Prime Deals The next stage of DAO2DAO coordination is here: Prime Deals enables DAOs to execute token swaps, joint ventures, and more with tools for DAO2DAO networked cooperation.      Forefront Lastly (for now), I’ve shared info about Index Coop’s $SOCIAL launch elsewhere in the Forum. It’s important to highlight – and happy to share some alpha for anyone reading this – that every single one of the communities comprising this index has a nice sized treasury today and few are catering to them. The Amazons and Twitters of the future are likely to be among these emerging DAOs. Yes, really. I started crafting a reply but in writing the reply I started Looking for Maker Mission statement. So I start searching… This pops out. MakerDAO — Technology Pioneers 2020 Then The Maker Protocol White Paper | Feb 2020 and with some irony 3rd google hit. Display MakerDAO Mission Stmt on Forum Front Page The Maker Forum Display MakerDAO Mission Stmt on Forum Front Page Hi, I’m new to MKR governance, love the community here. I’d like suggest displaying MakerDAO’s mission statement on the front page of the forum to guide day-to-day governance actions. This will be very helpful to newbies like myself. Thanks! P.S. mission-driven tech company like Tesla display their mission statement (“Accelerate the world’s tra… First link gives what may or may not be an accurate representation of the Maker mission statement but at least it is concise. "The vision behind MakerDAO is to create a decentralized, transparent and accessible platform to level the economic playing field for everybody around the world." When I read it I like to think Maker has held to the vision as stated above but then when you look at each piece (decentralized, transparent, accessible). The standout where Maker is failing imo. “accessible”, and honestly “decentralized”. Perhaps it is time for MakerDAO to reconstruct and re-affirm an actual vision via a Mission statement. North Star - lets get past remaking the wheel by using new terms. The only link that comes up in a search as a concise Maker Mission statement is a ‘third party’ link above which to my mind illustrates that MakerDAO and Maker in general has lost it’s way and needs to either re-affirm or re-define the Maker mission statement. It is now what almost 6 years since the first whitepaper.   Ethereum, Maker, and the whole crypto ecosystem is a vastly different landscape since the first vision and mission statement was conceived.   Perhaps it is time to discuss the Maker Mission and come up with a mission statement and use this to guide efforts, funding, and measuring tangible results.

You are actually proving the extent to which we are decentralized, transparent and accessible by your comments! This is the beauty of the frustration many are experiencing. Everything is transparent and accessible. Anyone can (and does) create an account here and immediately is recognized as part of the community with the ability to vote on issues at their most critical stage (early signals of community support and sentiment). Our product offerings while expensive are impressively accessible! The friction is a feature and not a bug of being a large decentralized community with many stakeholders. It resists capture to special interests and levers of power that work in the old system do not work here. What will work is a compelling vision, merit and emotionally intelligent conduct that draws the community together in a coherent direction. The right language is essential to moving forward. I suggest that to the extent we feel stuck, new terms are exactly what we need to better comprehend where we’ve been, where we are, and where we need to go.

I love this forum post. And it is extremely well written. Kudos and chapeau. Combining this with the erstwhile vision behind MakerDAO, leads to a powerful guiding star.     MakerMan:  “The vision behind MakerDAO is to create a decentralized, transparent and accessible platform to level the economic playing field for everybody around the world.”   DAOs so far have been fortunate to arrive in a market flush with capital where selling tokens or founders crypto-holdings meant monetary constraints were practically non-existent. This is likely to change though. Would maker want to be the lender serving entities that by all means cannot get a line of credit in the “real world”? I think it should. We’re currently witnessing the birth of a completely new model of organising enterprises that allows for unprecedented scaling. The amount of DAOs starting and growing is only going to rise in the next years. MakerDAO can offer something that no other crypto lender can. The amount of knowledge and experience, plus the quality of the network are second to none. I wholeheartedly agree with your vision and think the concept of driving organic demand for DAI should be our north star. It’s not a hard sell, either. I will repeat it as often as possible to drive this point home. Maker has one product, and one product only: DAI. Whatever drives demand for that product is in the interest of Maker. Personally, I wouldn’t worry too much about the minutiae of implementation at first but would want to make sure that this vision of organic DAI is shared and understood by everyone. Again thank you for your post and thanks @ACREinvest for the backup and the alpha on DAOs.

Brilliant post and incredibly well written. I’m noticing a trend where Maker’s Real World Finance cadre are bringing some serious literary heat to the table (@teej now joining @luca_pro and @SebVentures). I’ll never make fun of bankers and accountants for being boring again… On a more inquisitive note, a seemingly important aspect I don’t see mentioned is the distinction around legal capabilities and risks. When discussing RWA especially, this seems particularly relevant and arugably of more importance over credit-risk (assuming credit-risk doesn’t include legal risk). The inherent reliance on legal structures for RWA can be viewed both as a source of strength and a cause for challenge when it comes to doing business. And Maker’s natural ambiguity on the subject creates a similar dynamic of having benefits and detriments. And as always, there isn’t clear answers or any one single direction to take on the topic. How does the collective RWF team view the legal dimension when it comes to DAI’s future and growth? Before the legal and crypto-native worlds mature and extend furhter into each other’s domain, what assumptions can we make now? What threats or opportunities do we see?

The post is really two posts combined. One: organic DAI as a north star. This is important and necessary. Two: Using D3M and RWA as means to this end. I like the point that @teej is making here and believe that these strategies will bear ample fruit. But Maker is a decentralized organisation and it could experiment with ways on how this end is achieved and what the risk/reward ratio is. Personally, I think that risk is a necessary component of any venture, and should not be shied away from. RWA is a huge opportunity and Maker is one of the leading forces in that space.

Khan:  On a more inquisitive note, a seemingly important aspect I don’t see mentioned is the distinction around legal capabilities and risks. When discussing RWA especially, this seems particularly relevant and arugably of more importance over credit-risk (assuming credit-risk doesn’t include legal risk).   Legal risk is, in many ways, a subset of credit risk. i.e. if legal structure is weak, the odds of losing money are of course higher, hence credit risk. With that said, we’ve put forth a taxonomy of risks inherent to RWAs here:  Screen Shot 2022-05-01 at 11.14.34 AM1920×1069 102 KB  We’ve been fairly public about our dogged focus on rigorous legal structuring. In fact, many community members and token holders have expressed frustration regarding how slowly we are advancing RWA production due to obsession with getting the infrastructure correct. As examples of this obsession, see a thorough review of 6S’ structure and the good-faith efforts put forth by Centrifuge to improve MKR token-holders RWA protections here and here. Despite the impatience and general short attention spans endemic to crypto, RWF intends to onboard assets the right way. Build resilient credit + legal infrastructure first, then scale. HVB will be greenlit tomorrow. @christiancdpetersen @Eumenes and I will put forward in the coming weeks, de novo, a dependable structure that is repeatable for RWAs going forward. This process will be complimented by external counsel, a collateral verification agent, a trustee, etc. It’s going to be awesome.     Khan:  How does the collective RWF team view the legal dimension when it comes to DAI’s future and growth? Before the legal and crypto-native worlds mature and extend furhter into each other’s domain, what assumptions can we make now? What threats or opportunities do we see?   As mentioned, the legal dimension is critical for RWAs and those D3M opportunities that are not smart-contract guaranteed. @Khan - Thank you for the questions. I would define “legal risk” broadly to include:   Legal structure risk - How does the legal structure protect Maker’s interests and how robust is the structure in downside scenarios/bankruptcy? Set and forget is not a good approach.   Commercial risk - Does the transaction address the material commercial issues? If not, what is missing? Are the terms reasonable, balanced and protective of Maker?   Contract risk - How well drafted are the contracts that underpin the transaction? What terms are missing? We are not yet at the stage where we can solely rely on a “smart contract” - it is still very much traditional contracting with a digital overlay. This is one of the areas I want to evolve and I think that Maker can influence.   Regulatory/Legal risk - This category is very broad and can include an assortment of risks and will depend on the jurisdiction.   From a legal perspective, the biggest threat to the successful deployment and repayment of DAI is poorly constructed contracts and legal structures. Having advised on commercial transactions in over 40 countries, I have seen lots of good, bad, creative and otherwise. But I fully acknowledge even gold plated contracts do not help if the underlying credit is bad. I think there is an opportunity to scale, attract strong users, and get repaid by implementing higher quality contracts and legal structures. I am not looking for perfection, but rather contractual terms and legal structures that have been demonstrated to work in achieving scale, attracting strong users, and getting repaid. There is regulatory/legal risk of course, but those tend to be outside of our control.     Khan:  I’ll never make fun of bankers and accountants for being boring again…   And lawyers? Although I can understand if not.

As others mentioned, accessibility is core to Maker’s original mission statement. Amongst all of the praise, allow me to take a contrarian stance here and argue that your post makes some major mistakes about how Maker works. You posit that there are two forms of borrowing, one where the borrower sells the DAI and one where they hold onto the DAI and use it in some form (e.g. LPing). In reality, this “borrow and hold” use case is very rare and highly specific to crypto. In the real world, people take loans to buy stuff (leverage) so this is the most organic form of borrowing you can have. In other words, DAI borrowed in vaults is supposed to be sold. Instead of one, there are two types of DAI demand: The demand to borrow it, and the demand to hold it. Both are important and in practice you should expect no overlap between them. At a later point, you seem to confuse loans with deposits. DAI holders, not CDP owners, are the depositors in our system. This ties neatly into the point about the two sides of DAI demand, as DAI holders (depositors) are lending money to Maker in return for interest (the DSR, currently 0%), and Maker is re-lending it to CDP owners for interest (the SF, varying but positive.) The spread between the two rates is our profit. How are the two demand types currently balanced? It may not be obvious, but we have too much demand to hold DAI and not nearly enough demand to borrow and sell DAI. The result is DAI consistently trading above $1, which only gets arbitraged down to $1 by minting DAI from USDC at 0% SF and has led to >50% of all DAI in circulation being backed by USDC. Our North Star, if we have any, hence has to be to grow the two sides of our market (holding and borrowing DAI) equally. In the medium term, the focus should be on improving our offering for borrowers, not DAI holders. If we succeed in that, it will also help to reduce the existential tail risk from USDC backing most of DAI.

This is a good post.  I agree in principle that you need to grow loans and deposits.  I will point out that the USDC PSM is rapidly trending downward so it’s not clear where we are with DAI demand at the current moment.  What I think is interesting about all this DAI demand talk is that it’s really easy to create DAI demand.  With a flip of the switch, you can increase the DSR and increase demand.  So I do agree with @hasu that we need to focus on our lending operations.  We need revenue with good margins that can be turned into a higher rate.  As macro environment changes, we need different borrowers to choose from.  Banks get to lend deposits to each other at the fed funds rate without really losing much liquidity.  So they can easily find loan demand to make money on any reserve surplus they have.  MKR doesn’t really have that luxury so you have to find other ways like buying short term treasuries to be able compete on rates.  However, you also don’t have reserve requirements imposed upon you so you kind of manage your own liquidity risks.  Maybe one day, if governments recognize stability and liquidity of DAI and you have some kind of protocol that efficiently connects banks to MKR, banks could turn to MKR (instead of other banks or the fed) to fulfill reserve requirements using DAI.  It would become as simple as increasing the debt ceiling to a vault.  But right now, the process of finding loan demand in order to efficiently put extra deposits to use is a little clunky.

When you explain the concept of “Organic Dai” it reminds me of venmo dollars. Venmo users collect money on Venmo and exchange within the app between users. There is value in holding Venmo dollars in the application to be exchanged within the ecosystem. Users can also “cash-out” of the app to be redeemed into their bank accounts. Venmo dollars are just a means to an end. Organic Dai is the desire to hold Dai as an asset. Similar to holding a Venmo dollar. My understanding of TJ’s analysis is that RWA will increase the “holding power” of Dai. Very large, institutional real estate firms, will hold Dai to transact within the network. This can only happen if MakerDAO has enough RWA value to stay in its ecosystem. I agree with TJ, this is not realistic for a few years. Market behavior is not there yet. TJ’s point about “the distinction between RWA and D3M will disappear” is interesting. Based on the definition, the range of what a D3M can be is huge. I think there will be “derivatives” of D3Ms. For example, real estate. SkyVest aims to be a “derivative” of a D3M, like Centrifuge. A robust ecosystem of “derivatives” will develop on top of D3M’s for different RWA use-cases. TJ’s point, as I understand it, is that RWA on a D3M has double-sided risk. RWA’s credit risk and D3M’s smart contract risk. It is particularly trickier than either on their own. TJ’s thought process on B2B Dai vs. EZ Dai is an interesting differentiation. They both require an intermediary, like an exchange or DAO, the only difference is the type of investor. B2B Dai is safer, and qualifies for wholesale lending, because they are lending capital to businesses and institutions. EZ Dai is being lent to retail investors, which is inherently more risky. Figure and Mortgage are great examples of platform use-cases for EZ Dai. Access Vaults are Maker liquidity for exchanges to distribute to retail investors and Corporate Vaults are Maker liquidity for DAO’s or D3M’s for institutions/businesses. This is how I understood the post and my two cents. Any feedback is more than appreciated! Thank you @teej for the thoughtful piece!
